pullRequest.title: Add error handling & retry in ArtifactDownloader
pullRequest.bodyText:
Issue #, if available:
https://sim.amazon.com/issues/P40837097
Description of changes:


ArtifactDownloader can resume downloading from disconnected network or partially downloaded file.


ArtifactDownloader now does retry when getting artifact info.


GreengrassRepositoryDownloader handles more HTTP response codes.


Add ArtifactDownloaderFactory to replace selectArtifactDownloader() in ComponentManager


Refactor to move downloading&checksum logic into parent ArtifactDownloader class. Sub downloader class only need to implement download(), getArtifactFilename() , getDownloadSize() .


Added generic runWithRetry() method


Refactor to make ArtifactDownloader non-singleton. Each download will generate a downloader object. The downloader object can preserve download context.


Add tests


Why is this change necessary:
How was this change tested:
UAT - component-11  & component-16
Any additional information or context required to review the change:
Checklist:

 Updated the README if applicable
 Updated or added new unit tests
 Updated or added new integration tests
 Updated or added new end-to-end tests

By submitting this pull request, I confirm that you can use, modify, copy, and redistribute this contribution, under the terms of your choice.

commit.message:
Add error handling & retry in ArtifactDownloader

* ArtifactDownloader can resume downloading from disconnected network or partially downloaded file.
* ArtifactDownloader now does retry when getting artifact info.
* S3Downloader now checks retryable() in returned AWS client errors.
* GreengrassRepositoryDownloader handles more HTTP response codes.

* Refactor to move downloading&checksum logic into parent ArtifactDownloader class.
* Refactor to make ArtifactDownloader non-singleton. Each download will generate a downloader object.
* Add ArtifactDownloaderFactory
* Add tests

nodes.bodyText:
sketchy...
If the retries should be configurable, just make it configurable.
Algorithm missing from artifact
you can't just fail us here. This breaks local deployment doesn't it?

not sure about this whole offset business. Seems that you're trying to allow for partial downloads to resume?
If that's the case, then you should calculate the checksum after downloading so that you can be sure that the resuming actually worked and the download wasn't corrupt.
you can't do this, you need to provide somewhere in the string for that object to be converted to a string.
add GGExtension
Why do we have to use reflection like this? Can we avoid it?
Why not move out the exception class?
If this shouldn't happen, just remove this piece of code?

Nit - if we're going to log, better emphasize on the important piece of information, that there was an existing file which was partially downloaded, so something like Found existing partially downloaded file with size {}, will continue downloading or something.
Nit - could read better as runWithRetry
Nit - why is this method called localFileName since this seems to be just filename in general that you use no matter if it's cloud or local deployment?
This shouldn't be needed, Michael had a PR some time ago to avoid cloud call, it got reverted later but it's still planned I think
Same as above, this needs to go away
What happens if the network is completely off?
Both getDownloadSizeNoRetry and getArtifactFilenameNoRetry use standard AWS SDK, which already has built-in retry logic. Why not just configure the SDK to retry?

commit.message: Address comments. Move retry logic to client side

nodes.bodyText: log the expected file size and actual file size.
Refactor this to its own method
This is duplicate logic to line 130. may as well just have one place to delete corrupted/unmatch files.
Have you considered to refactor this to a utility class? Then it's also easier to write unit tests.

hmmmm...throwing this exception up here is questionable. What do we expect the customers to respond to this? Is this considered a user error that customers need to take action? Since our cloud service generates the digest from the artifact, most likely the exception is due to file corruption that happens on the device. I think we should retry on this.

Why is there an infinite loop here? Isn' there retry in the readWithRange already? Even if we want to handle the network disconnect case, shouldn't that be within readWithRange as readWithRange is the method that does the download.

I don't like this method return an InputStream. It breaks the logic of download to two parts. Now you need to handle retry on both places. Can we just merge them into one method and have a separate implementation for each downloader? Then we can see what are the common code that can be extracted out.
this isn't threadsafe if we download in parallel at all, the kvs would be mismatched
Removing and retrying download
add context (a message) to this error log
download shouldn't be closing the input stream, since it is closed here, right?
don't call toString
use logger.createChild otherwise you are adding these defaults to the logger for ArtifactDownload because loggers created with the same name (the class name) aren't unique, they are the same logger.
nit: don't use magic number. Extract 3 to a constant.
why not also declare inputstream in the try with block?
Why is this exception swallowed?

return null is usually a bad idea. For example, inside the GreengrassRepositoryDownloader.download method where runWithRetry is called, the expected return type is long. Unboxing a null Long to long will throw NPE. It's not going to be pretty.
Think about when InterruptedException will be threw and how it should be handled, not just locally but across the whole running program.

This is still not ideal. InterruptedException is an expected behavior. It happens when the whole program is to be shut down. Wrapping it inside an PackageDownloadException which is an error case doesn't seem right. For this method, it can just stop and populate the InterruptedException up and let its caller (or caller's caller) handle it. The caller who manages the lifecycle of the current running thread is the right place to handle Interrupted exception.
Can you please also add a log here?
